Review that -er and -or are suffixes that are added to some verbs to form nouns. The suffixes can mean a person who or something that does.
Explain that some base words require spelling changes before adding suffixes, such as dropping the final e or doubling the final consonant.
Write the word drum. Read it aloud and have students repeat.

Model how to add -er to drum to form the word drummer. Point out the spelling change and have students read the new word (double final consonant because word ends in one consonant and there is a single short vowel before it). Explain that a drummer is a person who plays the drums.
Repeat with create and the suffix -or. Discuss the spelling change (drop finale because suffix starts with a vowel). Explain that a creator is someone who creates.
Continue by adding -er or -or to these words: win (winner), senate (senator), grow (grower), educate (educator). Guide students to read the words and identify any spelling changes to the base word.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
/ square. Add a square to show me
Students should add a different color square after the purple /
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /

Dictate the following sentences for students to write, one at a time:
The diners notice that the waiter is very busy. The narrator tells the story of a great warrior.
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles.
Each riddle contains clues about a noun. Students must identify the word.
For the first reading, read the first riddle and have students read the other riddles. Invite volunteers to solve each riddle.
Then have students reread the riddles in pairs, alternating lines. Partners can switch lines during the rereadings.

Model how to add -er to drum to form the word drummer. Point out the spelling change and have students read the new word (double final consonant because word ends in one consonant and there is a single short vowel before it). Explain that a drummer is a person who plays the drums.
Repeat with create and the suffix -or. Discuss the spelling change (drop finale because suffix starts with a vowel). Explain that a creator is someone who creates.

Review that -er and -or are suffixes that are added to some verbs to form nouns. The suffixes can mean a person who or something that does.
Explain that some base words require spelling changes before adding suffixes, such as dropping the final e or doubling the final consonant.
Write the word drum. Read it aloud and have students repeat.

Model how to add -er to drum to form the word drummer. Point out the spelling change and have students read the new word (double final consonant because word ends in one consonant and there is a single short vowel before it). Explain that a drummer is a person who plays the drums.
Repeat with create and the suffix -or. Discuss the spelling change (drop finale because suffix starts with a vowel). Explain that a creator is someone who creates.
Continue by adding -er or -or to these words: win (winner), senate (senator), grow (grower), educate (educator). Guide students to read the words and identify any spelling changes to the base word.
